user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_QueueGetInfo(osal_id_t queue_id, OS_queue_prop_t *queue_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_prop);

    memset(queue_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_queue_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_queue_table, token);

        strncpy(queue_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(queue_prop->name) - 1);
        queue_prop->creator = record->creator;

        /*
         * Currently there are no additional queue details provided by the impl layer -
         * But this could be added in the future (i.e. current/max depth, msg size, etc)
         */

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_queue_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_queue_table
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rule 8.13 suggests pointers should be to const-qualified types when the pointed-to object is not modified. In this function the local pointer 'record' is only used to read fields (e.g. record->name_entry, record->creator) and is assigned from the global table via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET/OS_global_queue_table; therefore the pointer-to-record and the global table/macro should be investigated for possible const qualification. Other pointers and fragments are not suspicious for this rule: - The function parameter 'OS_queue_prop_t *queue_prop' is actively written (memset, strncpy, field assignments), so it cannot be const. - The token passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById and OS_ObjectIdRelease is modified by those routines (initialization, conversion, release), so the token pointer cannot be const. - The OS_CHECK_POINTER macro only validates the pointer and does not imply the pointed-to object could be const. - Calls and definitions related to OS_ObjectIdGetById/Release operate on mutable transaction/token state and therefore are intentionally non-const. Accordingly, only the table access and the record pointer usage are reported for investigation under Rule 8.13.
